1. Introduction

Achieving consistent encoding within a given community of practice has been a recurrent issue for the TEI Guidelines. The topic is of particular importance for lexical data if we think of the potential wealth of content we could gain from pooling together the information available in the variety of highly structured, historical and contemporary lexical resources. Still, the encoding possibilities offered by the Dictionaries Chapter in the Guidelines are too numerous and too flexible to guarantee sufficient interoperability and a coherent model for searching, visualising or enriching multiple lexical resources.

Following the spirit of TEI Analytics [Zillig, 2009], developed in the context of the MONK project, TEI Lex-0 aims at establishing a baseline encoding and a target format to facilitate the interoperability of heterogeneously encoded lexical resources. This is important both in the context of building lexical infrastructures as such [Ermolaev and Tasovac, 2012] and in the context of developing generic TEI-aware tools such as dictionary viewers and profilers. T

TEI Lex-0 should not be thought of as a replacement of the Dictionary Chapter in the TEI Guidelines or as the format that must be used for editing or managing individual resources, especially in those projects and/or institutions that already have established workflows based on their own flavors of TEI. TEI Lex-0 should be primarily seen as a format that existing TEI dictionaries can be univocally transformed to in order to be queried, visualised, or mined in a uniform way. At the same time, however, there is no reason why TEI Lex-0 could not or should not be used as a best-practice example in educational settings or as a set of best-practice guidelines for new TEI-based projects, especially considering the fact that in TEI Lex-0 we aimed to stay as aligned as possible with the TEI subset developed in conjunction with the revision of the ISO LMF (Lexical Markup Framework) standard (cf. [Romary, 2015])

1.1. Context

Preliminary work for the establishment of TEI Lex-0 started in the Working Group "Retrodigitised Dictionaries" lead by Toma Tasovac and Vera Hildenbrandt as part of the COST Action European Network of e-Lexicography (ENeL). Upon the completion of the COST Action, the work on TEI Lex-0 was taken up by the DARIAH Working Group "Lexical Resources" which is co-chaired by Laurent Romary and Toma Tasovac. Currently, the work on TEI Lex-0 is conducted by the DARIAH WG "Lexical Resources" and the H2020-funded European Lexicographic Infrastructure (ELEXIS).

The above paragraph should be expanded to include a list of meetings we organized, who sponsored them etc.

1.2. Dictionary model vs. XML serialization

A fundamental principle that the present enterprise relies on is the nature of the mapping of the physical or “near-physical” (OCR-ed) dictionary contents onto the abstract model of a dictionary structure, and the mapping from said model onto its (in our case) TEI XML serialization. It is important to keep in mind the distinction between the abstract model and its serialization because, as we shall see, the TEI uses the same elements of the abstract model to serve many kinds of text-modelling tasks, and standardly employs ‘features’ or ‘facets’ of these elements (known in the XML world as attributes) to express differences among them. The fact that some elements of the serialization have names closely corresponding to what we can customarily find in the dictionary model is more or less a lucky coincidence. It is not the pattern to be expected. A lexicographer coming from outside of the TEI universe should not necessarily expect his or her customary terms (names of dictionary objects in the dictionary model) to be straightforwardly reflected in the TEI vocabulary names.

Take, for instance, the TEI element <cit>. Originally, its TEI name came from the word “citation” and this is what the element was used for up to the early days of TEI P5, when it acquired a new, broader function of grouping together pieces of text perceived or broadly treated as “foreign” or additional, together with their (bibliographic, linguistic, or usage-oriented) description. This element is nowadays used as a “container” for citations, dictionary examples, translation equivalents etc. The value of the attribute type is used to further specify the kind of cit-object at hand. In our case, four distinct names of dictionary objects in the abstract dictionary model (namely, “citation”, “example”, “translation” (of quotes) and “translation equivalent” (of words) map onto four distinct element+attribute combinations in the TEI XML serialization (respectively, <cit> with type="citation", <cit> with type="example", and <cit> with type="translation" or type="translationEquivalent".Note: We need to discuss the possible reference to attestation and link this to LMF (part 1 - or rather 2?)

The following example from a bilingual dictionary, shows how one typed element – <cit> – can be used to encode different parts of the dictionary structure:

<entry xml:lang="fr">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>horrifier</orth>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">v</gram>  </gramGrp>  <sense>   <cit type="translationEquivalent"    xml:lang="en">    <quote>horrify</quote>   </cit>   <cit type="example">    <quote>elle était horrifiée par la dépense</quote>    <cit type="translation" xml:lang="en">     <quote>she was horrified at the expense</quote>    </cit>   </cit>  </sense> </entry>

1.3. Treatment of source information

This section needs to be written! Or we get rid of it for 0.7 and add it later.

Another part of this introduction should address the use of textual elements that are seen as spurious from the point of view of the goals of TEI-Lex0 and the role that <dictScrap> and <pc> play in this; cases under discussion should involve, e.g., commas that have or do not have structural correlates, square brackets for pronunciation information.

[What we need as well is unified treatment of abbreviations, corrections/normalization, ‘highlighting’, responsibilityNote: done: `@resp` is now a global attribute, and a strategy for milestones, such as page numbers; the DCR attributes should also get mentioned]

[bibliographic references have to be discussed as well, note the cit/bibl issue (where bibl is the only child of cit)]

When we say that we “remove something”, we’re not saying that we want to get rid of it from the TEI -- we’re only addressing TEI-Lex0. This should be said in the introduction.

2. Entries and entry-like objects

2.1. Unified representation of entries

In the current guidelines, the TEI defines four different container elements that may serve as grouping devices for lexical information on the level of entries (the following definitions are taken from the TEI guidelines, emphasis added):

  1. <entry>: contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
  2. <entryFree>: contains a single unstructured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.
  3. <superEntry>: groups a sequence of entries within any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon which function as a single unit, for example a set of homographs.
  4. <re>: (related entry) contains a dictionary entry for a lexical item related to the headword, such as a compound phrase or derived form, embedded inside a larger entry.

These four elements can be used to distinguish types of entries along two conceptual axes:

  1. Containing vs. contained entries: entries may contain additional lexical information that can be conceived as an additional dictionary entry in its own right. Specifically, <superEntry> may contain <entry> and <entry> in turn may contain <re> to represent the embedding of lexical entries on three distinct levels. Due to <re> being allowed to be used recursively, the number of levels for representing entry-like lexical information inside other such blocks is effectively unrestricted.
  2. Structured vs. unstructured entries, i. e. entries that can readily be represented (in the lexical view) in the spirit of the TEI Guideline’s dictionary chapter (<entry>, <re>) vs. entries that for some reason violate the generic content model of <entry> or <re> and thus have to be represented more freely (<entryFree>). A third category in this respect are entries that exhibit a highly reduced amount of lexical content while this content is still of essentially entry-like nature (<superEntry>).

In TEI Lex-0, we refrain from this overly complex cross-classification of entries with regard to their place within an entry hierarchy (first axis above) and the rigidity of the lexical structuring they exhibit (second axis above). Instead of using four different elements for entry-like objects, only <entry> is used. In order to still be able to construct hierarchies of embedded entries, <entry> will need to be allowed to occur recursively (e. g. by making it part of <model.entrypart.top>). However, this leads to a non conservative deviation from the TEI guidelines.

In the context of TEI-Lex-0, the following new definition for <entry> is used: <entry> is used as the Note: doesn't this restrict <entry> to the top level? Maybe instead an appeal to a "complete functional complex" would help? (The exact term is Chomskyan; I'm not sure how good it would be to re-use it verbatim)Note: I rephrased it from "the higest element" to "the basic element". Also, I changed the definition to refer to "linguistic entity" (i.e. often more or less a "complete functional complex", but this term is bound in syntax (wouldn't easily fit for Arabic dictionaries where top-level-entries may describes stems)). And the term is related to a specific linguistic theory so yes – not directly usable here.)basic element in the microstructure; it comprises all information related to a linguistic entity and may contain further entries related to it (e. g. homographs or compound phrases).

The substitution of <re> and <superEntry> by <entry> is compatible with regard to the content model of the discarded elements. Both <re> and <superEntry> have content models that are proper subsets of the content model of <entry>. Instead of <superEntry> which most typically is used as a mere container for grouping lexical entries, either an <entry> grouping entries can be used or the mechanisms implemented by att.global.linking can be exploited.

Consider the following excerpt from the “Wörterbuch der deutschen Gegenwartssprache” (“Dictionary of present-day German”, WDG, 1964–1977). In the WDG, compounds with the same morphological dependant (but different heads) are grouped into nests. According to the current TEI guidelines, such a nest would most probably be serialized as follows:

<superEntry>  <form>   <orth>Haus-</orth>, <orth>haus-</orth>:</form> <!-- possibly some shared usg information -->  <entry>   <form>    <orth expand="Hausaltar">-altar</orth>, <gramGrp>     <gen value="masculine">der</gen>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry>  <entry>   <form>    <orth expand="Hausandacht">-andacht</orth>, <gramGrp>     <gen value="feminine">die</gen>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry> <!-- ... --> </superEntry>

In TEI-Lex-0, this nest of entries would be modelled as an <entry> in its own right. Note that the former <superEntry> was transformed into a typed entry (see Types of entries below for a detailed discussion of entry types):

<entry type="wordFamily">  <form type="base">   <orth>Haus-</orth>  </form>  <pc>,</pc>  <form type="base">   <orth>haus-</orth>  </form>  <pc>:</pc> <!-- possibly some shared usg information -->  <entry type="wordForm">   <form type="lemma">    <orth expand="Hausaltar">-altar</orth>    <pc>,</pc>    <gramGrp>     <gen value="masculine">der</gen>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry>  <entry type="wordForm">   <form type="lemma">    <orth expand="Hausandacht">-andacht</orth>    <pc>,</pc>    <gramGrp>     <gen value="feminine">die</gen>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry> <!-- ... --> </entry>

The same encoding strategy can be exploited when entries are grouped under a common morphological root as is customary for Arabic dictionaries such as the 48th edition of “The Dictionary of Language and Proper Nouns” (المنجد في اللغة والأعلام) presented below:

<entry type="wordFamily">  <form type="root">   <orth>ﺍﺮﻛ</orth>   <pc>:</pc>  </form>  <entry n="١-" type="wordForm">   <form type="lemma">    <orth>ﺃَﺮَﻛَ</orth> -ُ ﺃُﺮُﻛًﺍ</form>   <sense> ﺎﻠﺠﻤﻟُ: ﺎﻜﻟ ﻭﺮﻗ ﺍﻷﺭَﺎﻛِ ٠ ﺃَﺮَﻛَ ٠- ﺃَﺮَﻛًﺍ ﺎﻠﺠﻤﻟُ ﺎﺸﺘﻛﻯ      ﺐﻄﻨﻫُ ﻢﻧ ﺄَﻜﻟ ﺍﻷﺭَﺎﻛِ ٠ ﺍﻷﺭﺎﻛ (ﻥ): ﻭﺎﺣﺪﺘﻫُ ﺃَﺭﺎﻛﺓ ﺝ ﺃُﺮُﻛ ﻭ      ﺃَﺭَﺎﺌِﻛ. ﺶﺟﺭ ﺫﻭ ﺵﻮﻛ. ﻁﻮﻴﻟ ﺎﻠﺳﺎﻗ، ﻚﺜﻳﺭ ﺎﻟﻭﺮﻗ ﻭ ﺍﻸﻐﺻﺎﻧ. ﺥﻭَّﺍﺭ      ﺎﻠﻋﻭﺩ ﺖﺘَّﺧﺫ ﻢﻨﻫ ﺎﻠﻤﺳﺍﻮﻴﻛ</sense>  </entry>  <entry n="٢٠ -" type="wordForm">   <form type="lemma">    <orth>ﺃَﺮَﻛَ</orth>   </form>   <sense> ْ -َ ﺃَﺮَﻛًﺍ ﻭ ﺃَﺮِﻛَ ْ -ُ ﺃُﺮﻛًﺍ ﺎﻠﺟﺮﺣُ: ﺏﺭﺃَ</sense>  </entry> <!-- … --> </entry>

Note that the embedded entries are enumerated by way of the attribute @n.

This type of grouping is also customarily used in dictionaries of word-families in other languages such as in Howard H. Keller’s (1978): “A German word family dictionary together with English equivalents”:

<entry type=”word-family”>

<entry type=”main”>

<form><orth>Haus</orth><gramGrp><pos>nn</pos></gramGrp></form>

<sense>...</sense>

</entry>

<entry type=”sub”>

<form><orth><m>Häus</m> <m>chen</m></orth></gramGrp></form>

<sense>...</sense>

</entry>

<entry type=”sub”>

<form><orth><m>haus</m> <m>en</m></orth></gramGrp></form>

<sense>...</sense>

</entry>

</entry>

In the Collins/COBUILD “Dictionary of Idioms” (2nd. ed., 2002), idioms are grouped under a common headword. No additional information for the headword is provided; it only serves as part of the access structure for the idioms. This can also be modelled using recursive entries. Again, see Types of entries for a discussion of possible entry types:

<entry type="simple">  <form>   <orth>house</orth>  </form>  <entry type="multiWordExpression">   <form>    <orth>bring the house down</orth>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry>  <entry type="multiWordExpression">   <form>    <orth>eat someone out of house and home</orth>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry>  <entry type="multiWordExpression">   <form>    <orth>get on like a house on fire</orth>   </form>   <sense>...</sense>  </entry> </entry>

For <entryFree>, the content model is defined more freely than for <entry>. To account for entries that do not follow the rather strict lexical model envisioned by the TEI guidelines for <entry>, <dictScrap> within <entry> shall be used.

2.2. Changes to the content model of <entry>

Within TEI-Lex-0, <entry> may contain the following elements: <form>, <sense>, <entry>, <etym>, <gramGrp>, <usg>, <xr>, <pc>Note: Will be allowed in vanilla TEI in the short term., and <dictScrap>. Contrary to the current TEI guidelines, it may not directly contain the following elements: <def>, <hom>, and <cit>. See the section Towards a more systematic use of <sense> below.

FROM VIENNA:

  • consensus: we are NOT getting rid of reNote: why???Note: Yes, why? In the last Berlin meeting (after Vienna), the consensus changed to: we do get rid of it.
  • for root based languages aNote: why not for compounds and derivates accompanying a main entrynd root-organized dictionariesNote: If you want to do something separate for root-organized dictionaries, then I would keep super entry to indicate the rootNote: See the proposed solution at the beginning of this section., we recommend: entry for the root, and then a bunch of re’s
  • re can be nested
  • we’re still getting rid of super entry.

2.3. Types of entries

Based on the proposed definition for <entry> in TEI-Lex-0, entries are conceived as “the most basic” elements of the microstructure. The examples provided in the section Unified representation of entries illustrate two applications of entries embedded within entries and make it obvious that different types of linguistic entities can be represented by <entry> in one single dictionary. Therefore, the provision of a @type attribute for <entry> is encouraged in such cases. The value for the type attribute shall denote a property of the entry as a whole that is not represented more specifically by way of other elements within the entry. It is for example not good practice to use e. g. the part-of-speech as the value for entry/@type because this information is encoded in gramGrp/pos.

The current TEI guidelines suggest the set of the following values for @type:

  • abbr
  • affix
  • foreign
  • hom
  • main
  • sub
  • supplemental
  • xref

Again, the list of values represent features from a considerable range of axes. Moreover, the features are not mutually exclusive (e. g. a foreign abbreviation may well be a homonym). The values belong to different domains: morphology (abbr), etymology (foreign), orthography and possibly phonology (hom), and (in a broad sense) the macrostructure of the dictionary (main, supplemental, xr). Of these domains, all except the dictionary’s macrostructure are catered for in specific elements below the level of the entry. They should therefore not be used as types of entries.

In general, the entry type can be applied locally for a single dictionary or globally to allow for classification across different dictionaries. Provided that a single dictionary will often comprise entries that describe linguistic entities of the same kind (“words”, word families, multi-word expressions, morphemes, …) a classification along those lines will be of minor importance for a stand-alone resource but may be useful in a multi-dictionary use-case. Possible values for this domain include:

  • affix
  • word
  • synsetNote: e.g. for onomasiological dictionariesNote: … though this is not the primary concern of the TEI it reads elsewhere in this text. (Laurent?)
  • multi-word-entity
  • word-family

A classification based on macrostructural properties (i. e. properties describing aspects of the internal organisation of a resource) can on the other hand be exploited both for a single dictionary and across different dictionaries. Possible values for this domain include:

  • main
  • supplemental
  • nest
  • niche
  • xr

TODO: Priviledge one strategy (discussion)?

3. Towards a more systematic use of <sense>

editors: Laurent, Mohamed

reviewer: Piotr

3.1. Guidelines

In the current TEI dictionary chapter, the content model of <entry> allows one to have sense-related information directly within <entry>. The present guidelines recommend a stricter use of these elements so that sense-related information is better localised within the <sense> element, in accordance with the underlying semasiological model implemented in the TEI Guidelines.

<sense> is thus made mandatory for any dictionary entry that actually provides sense information for the headword. Further in this document, we consider some additional specific cases (e.g. “referencing” entries, or inflexional lexica Note: At INT, we make a distinction between a dictionary and a computational lexicon. "inflectional lexica" are computational lexica, and for me TEI lex0 is not about computational lexicaNote: Then maybe a pronounciation dictionary? These also commonly don't have sense information.where the entry is limited to the provision of inflected forms), where <sense> is not a mandatory child of <entry>.

As a consequence of making the use of <sense> more systematic within <entry>, we have seen (see section on <entry>) that some elements are no longer allowed as children of <entry>. We provide here a specific background for each of them:

  • <def> is clearly intended to provide a prose description of a meaning within a <sense> element and should not appear in any other context;
  • In the same way, <cit> Note: might be an issue for dictionaries with citations (with bibl) in the etymology sectionand <usg> are recommended to be used exclusively as children of <sense>, or when necessary within <dictScrap>. In some rare cases, they may be used to document orthographic variants, when no specific sense description is intended;
  • The case of <hom> is peculiar since it provides a subordinate organization to an entry which is redundant to what <sense> allows one to represent. It is thusNote: Note that this recommendation strengthens the case for using gramGrp at the level of <sense> (which is welcome for independent reasons). recommended not to use this element at all within a dictionary entry.

Note: In the case one has to deal with information that does not fit a <sense>-based organization, for instance in the process of retro-digitizing an existing dictionary source, the use of <dictScrap> is recommended. Further step in the encoding of the lexical content may lead to a more precise encoding in a second phase.

3.2. A limited number of possible contexts for <def>

In the current TEI guidelines, <def> is allowed to be used within the following elements:

  • Module core: <cit>
  • Module dictionaries: <dictScrap>, <entry>, <entryFree>, <etym>, <hom>, <re>, <sense>
  • Module namesdates: <nym>

Apart from the case of <nym> (cf. note below), the present recommendations limit the use of <def> to <sense>, <cit> and <etym>. All other existing contexts would be implemented by embedding <def> within a <sense>.

Note: <nym> currently has a very sloppy content model taking up many elements from the dictionary chapter without eliciting clear encoding recommendations on their usage. In particular, examples associated to <nym> offer a very loose usage of such elements (e.g. using <form> without an <orth> element), which are even more in contradiction with the recommendation made in the present document. A possible recommendationNote: +1 for this. <nym> is a bit scary and it seems to me that it abuses the fact that <form>, being perhaps a somewhat overloaded element, has optional element content. could be to align <nym> to make it a simpler and specialized case of <entry> (sort of <entry type=”nym”>).

3.3. Encoding sense in entries with multiple parts of speech

For multi-POS lexical entries, the present recommendations consider each POS as a trigger for a new sense. Consequently, we recommend encoding grammatical information in each sense coming after the first one to be serialised inside the semantic bloc as follows:

<sense>  <gramGrp>   <pos>..</pos>  </gramGrp>  <def>..</def> .. </sense>

This is exemplified in the following example take from $$$, where arrest appears both as a verb and a noun:

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>arrest</orth>   <pron>/ə rest/</pron>   <gramGrp>    <pos>verb</pos>   </gramGrp>  </form>  <sense>   <usg>(of the police)</usg>   <def>to catch and hold someone who has broken the      law</def>   <cit type="example">    <quote>The police arrested two men and took them to        the police station</quote>   </cit>   <pc>.</pc>   <cit type="example">    <quote>He ended up getting arrested as he tried to        leave the country</quote>   </cit>   <pc>.</pc>   <cit type="example">    <quote>She was arrested for stealing</quote>   </cit>  </sense>  <pc>.</pc>  <sense>   <gramGrp>    <pos>noun</pos>   </gramGrp>   <def>the act of holding someone for breaking the      law</def>   <cit type="example">    <quote>The police made several arrests at the        demonstration</quote>   </cit>   <pc>.</pc>   <entry type="multiWordExpression">    <form>under arrest</form>    <sense>     <def>held by the police After the fight</def>     <pc>,</pc>     <cit type="example">      <quote>three people were under arrest</quote>     </cit>    </sense>   </entry>  </sense> </entry>

3.4. Case of bilingual dictionaries

Original excerpt for the entry aid from $$$
<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>Aid</orth>  </form>  <pc>,</pc>  <sense>   <gramGrp>    <pos>v.a.</pos>   </gramGrp>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form xml:lang="fr">     <orth>aider</orth>    </form>   </cit>   <pc>,</pc>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>assister</orth>    </form>   </cit>   <pc>,</pc>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>secourir</orth>    </form>   </cit>  </sense>  <pc>;</pc>  <sense>   <oRef>_</oRef>   <gramGrp>    <pos>s.</pos>   </gramGrp>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>aide</orth>    </form>   </cit>   <pc>,</pc>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <ort>assistance</ort>     <pc>,</pc>     <gramGrp>      <gen>f.</gen>     </gramGrp>    </form>   </cit>   <pc>,</pc>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>secours</orth>     <pc>,</pc>     <gramGrp>      <gen>m.</gen>     </gramGrp>    </form>   </cit>  </sense>  <pc>;</pc>  <sense>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>sub-side</orth>    </form>    <pc>,</pc>    <gramGrp>     <gen>m.</gen>    </gramGrp>   </cit>  </sense>  <pc>;</pc>  <sense>   <usg type="hint">(pers)</usg>   <cit type="equivalent">    <form>     <orth>aide</orth>    </form>    <pc>,</pc>    <gramGrp>     <gen>m.</gen>     <gen>f.</gen>    </gramGrp>   </cit>  </sense>  <entry type="multiWordExpression">   <form type="lemma">    <orth>By the <oRef>_</oRef> of</orth>   </form>   <pc>,</pc>   <sense>    <cit type="equivalent">     <form>      <orth>à l'aide de</orth>     </form>    </cit>   </sense>  </entry>  <pc>.</pc>  <entry type="multiWordExpression">   <form>    <orth>In <oRef>_</oRef> of</orth>   </form>   <pc>,</pc>   <sense>    <usg>(of performances)</usg>    <cit type="equivalent">au profit de</cit>    <pc>,</pc>    <cit type="equivalent">au bénéfice de</cit>   </sense>  </entry>  <pc>.</pc>  <entry type="derived">   <form type="lemma">    <orth>_less</orth>    <pc>,</pc>    <gramGrp>     <pos>adj.</pos>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <sense>    <cit type="equivalent">     <form xml:lang="fr">      <orth>sans aide</orth>     </form>    </cit>    <pc>,</pc>    <cit type="equivalent">     <form xml:lang="fr">      <orth>sans secours</orth>     </form>    </cit>   </sense>   <pc>;</pc>   <sense>    <cit type="equivalent">     <form>      <orth>abandonné</orth>     </form>    </cit>    <pc>,</pc>    <cit type="equivalent">     <form>      <orth>délaissé</orth>     </form>    </cit>   </sense>  </entry> </entry>

3.5. Deprecating <hom>

Making a clear difference between a situation where an entry has to be split into two or more homonyms and one where these differences correspond to a semantic alternation is lexicographically difficult.Note: Yes. This has been reiterated in the lexicographic and lexicological literature as the eternally debated split between polysemy and homonymy. Given the history of this issue and the heaps of paper devoted to it, I do _not_ think that glossing over this problem will do us any good. Specifically, the current recommendation is to ignore this issue altogether -- I don't see any mechanism that allows those who need this distinction to maintain it. This is not good, we're cutting away part of the target community in this way.I can't think of a coherent positive part to the present remark at this moment, unfortunately: I am afraid that `@type` is of no help in such cases. I could imagine a <join> element indicating groupings, e.g. groupings of senses into polysemous wholes (hmm, that could actually be worth a moment of discussion in Budapest, because of how versatile such a solution can be).Note: Thinking on this further: we could suggest a rule, whereby, _if_ someone needs to maintain a distinction between homonymy and polysemy in their dictionary, they use separate <entry> elements for the former, and the <sense> mechanism within a single entry for the latter. The drawback of this solution is that it imposes a structure in a content-driven setting (because our starting point is digitization of legacy dictionaries, unless I'm confused). So it may happen that the legacy dictionary keeps homonyms within a single <entry>, and then the above solution would fail.Note: True Still, the main danger in keeping both possibilities in the representation of a lexical entry in a digital lexicon is to introduce a systematic structural ambiguity as to where the appropriate information is to be found. We thus deprecate <hom> altogether in the present recommendation and have this element be replaced by the appropriate <sense > construct. For instance, the following TEI example:

<entry>  <form>   <orth>bray</orth>   <pron>breI</pron>  </form>  <hom>   <gramGrp>    <gram type="pos">n</gram>   </gramGrp>   <sense>    <def>cry of an ass; sound of a trumpet.</def>   </sense>  </hom>  <hom>   <gramGrp>    <gram type="pos">vt</gram>    <subc>VP2A</subc>   </gramGrp>   <sense>    <def>make a cry or sound of this kind.</def>   </sense>  </hom> </entry>

should actually be represented as follows:

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>bray</orth>   <pron>brel</pron>  </form>  <sense>   <gramGrp>    <pos>n</pos>   </gramGrp>   <sense>    <def>cry of an ass</def>   </sense>   <pc>;</pc>   <sense>    <def>sound of a trumpet</def>   </sense>  </sense>  <pc>.</pc>  <sense>   <gramGrp>    <pos>vt</pos>    <subc>VP2A</subc>   </gramGrp>   <def>make a cry or sound of this kind</def>  </sense>  <pc>.</pc> </entry>

3.6. Discussion notes

  • <sense> made mandatory for “typical entries” (take out def, usg, cit, etc.from entry TBD), @n for numbering
  • <usg>: mapping practices using @norm (recommendation)
    • <usg type=”time” norm=”old”>Vx.</usg>
    • collecting value lists
    • automatic classification experiment?
  • replacing <cit> by <oRef> for translation equivalent in the target language: make @type mandatory on <oRef> (TBD) — cf. rémoulade example in the guidelines; cf. gloss, mentioned, ref/xr, cit/@type=”translation”
  • …
  • [OK] leftover: deleting elements from <entry>
  • [OK] leftover: non “typical” entries: e.g. referencing other entries
  • leftover: representing frequency information in dictionary entries
  • leftover: <def>
  • where should we/could we have @xml:lang (have at least one? expanding inherited content? infoset)
  • <cit type=”attestation”>Note: applicable to all cit's - ;-) ? (by analogy to <form type=”lemma”>) Jack and Laurent have actually proposed that in their manuscript
  • “translation” in <cit type=”translation”> is actually an accident of history and controlled language. It comes from trans/tr (both were playing with the terms “translation” and “translation equivalent”). It should have been @type=“equivalent” rather than @type=”translation”. Accident and perhaps lack of the “feel” for right-headedness in compounds.

<cit type=”equivalent”>

<ref xml:lang=”fr” target=”french.xml#voiture”>voiture</ref>

…. (additional info)

</cit>

  • get rid of <gloss> in dictionaries, in favour of <def>
  • recommend that the use of <def> in bilingual dictionaries be restricted to “explaining” the sense (for instance the way Latin words are used to explain the senses of a Greek dictionary) rather than for providing translation equivalents?
  • we shouldn’t allow lang within sense

3.7.

  • no <oRef> any longer, it gets replaced by a typified <ref>. But note that <ref> doesn’t allow the @notation attribute (potential action point: add <ref> to att.notated)
  • we’re also getting rid of mentioned
  • Container Inside enTry = the element formerly known as “citation”Note: please no!

4. Recommendations concerning Written and Spoken FormsNote: +banski@ids-mannheim.de I'm making some decisions in my own project now and I just realized we never mentioned anything about how to label form types such as compounds and multi-word expressions, acronym, etc, which are also the lemma. One obvious solution would be to do <form type="lemma" subtype="compound">. Maybe we can discuss in LubljanaNote: It looks like the `@subtype` is going to receive a lot of heat. Let's base this on examples and see if we can handle them with just two "type" attributes

Editors: Piotr Bański, Jack Bowers, Tomaž Erjavec

Reviewer: Jesse, Katrien

The current TEI formulation allows for an extremely wide range of encoding possibilities. Below, we suggest ways in which the elements, in particular form, can be constrained. We give examples of use types not covered by the Guidelines, and propose some extensions.

4.1. A note on inheritance

We assume that in order to determine the complete properties of an element inside the entry tree, the principle of default inheritance applies, e.g. grammatical properties of a form are determined by collecting the sibling gramGrp of the ancestor-or-self of the focus element, where the superordinate grammatical properties can be overwritten by the lower-level properties. This principle is relatively straightforward in the case of grammatical properties, but more complex for the word paradigm, esp. in cases of variant forms. For more information c.f. Ide et al. (2000) and Erjavec et al. (2000).

4.2. Grammatical properties of lexical entries

Grammatical properties of lexical entries should be specified in entry/gramGrp. This element will typically specify the part-of-speech of the entry.

<entry xml:lang="en">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>on</orth>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">prep</gram>  </gramGrp> ... </entry>

Notes:

  1. Grammatical properties of the entry should not be specified in entry/form[@type=”lemma”]/gramGrp
  2. In cases where headwords are discriminated only on the basis of their orthography (e.g. in English dictionaries which treat conversion pairs of nouns and verbs, such as run, as belonging in single entries), entry/gramGrp should not be used, because its role is taken over by the individual sense/gramGrp. Note: In some of our dictionaries, the entry has a "summary" of the potential PoS and further specification is done at sense level. So this recommendation would not properly fit.Note: I am not sure if I understand this correctly, but if I do, it might be a dictScrap issue.Note: +katrien.depuydt@ivdnt.org i think we may need an example for this — to us it seems that we could have gramgrp both at the entry level and inside senses if that's how you have it in your print dictionary. wouldn't that work for you?Note: I think I understood what Katrien meant here. I also think that this restriction will cause an issue when it comes to encode any information which come just after the first pos and is related to the whole lexical entry. Etymology, for example (see the "aid" encoding example)Note: Hi guys, sorry it took so long, but here is an example:There is the preposition and adverb "achter". In the first red box, there is the summary. Below, the semantic descritpion per PoS is done in separate sections in which the grammatical information is repeated.Note: I think we should give up the restriction of gathering grammatical information in one spot and encode them just wherever they appearNote: [concerning the "achter" example] On the other hand we could also say that such categorial changes as part-of-speech should actually be encoded as separate embedded entries that happen to have some common information encoded in the parent. And here, the commonality is mostly the shared etymology and rather no strictly grammatical features.

<entry>

<form>

<orth>aid</orth>

<pron>/ed/</pron>

</form>

<gramGrp>

<pos>noun</pos>

</gramGrp>

<etym><usg type="date"><date>(early 15c.,)</date></usg>

</etym>Note: the etymological information here are prohibiting the move of the <gramGrp> under <sense>. Moving <gramGrp> would change the order of the original text informationNote: I don't see this dating in the facsimile. Where does it come from?Note: I just added it to illustrate the issue. I could look for a concrete exampleNote: I added <usg type="date"> as per <usg> and etym sections

<sense>

<sense>1. help, especially money, <lb/>food or other gifts given to people living <lb/>

in difficult conditions aid to the earth-<lb/>quake zone an aid worker (NOTE: This

<lb/>meaning of aid has no plural.) in aid <lb/>of in order to help We give money in <lb/>

aid of the Red Cross. They are collect-<lb/>ing money in aid of refugees</sense><pc>. </pc>

<sense>2. some-<lb/>thing which helps you to do something <lb/>kitchen aids</sense> í

</sense>

<sense>

<gramGrp>

<pos>verb</pos>

</gramGrp>

<sense>1. to help some-<lb/>thing to happen</sense>

<sense>2. to help someone</sense>

</sense>

</entry>

4.3.

4.4. Representation of the lemma

The form element should always be qualified by its type, where its values should be from the list of recommended (allowed?) values. The lemma (i.e. headword) form should be under form[@type=”lemma”].

If it is necessary to specify the grammatical properties of the lemma form itself (as opposed to the grammatical properties of the entry), this is described by entry/form[@type=”lemma”]/gramGrp, e.g.:

<form type="lemma">  <orth>go</orth>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="tense">present</gram>  </gramGrp> </form>

-Note: multi word expressions (<form type="lemma" subtype="MWE">)....

4.5. Representation of inflected forms

Dictionaries often include additional forms next to the lemma which are (in English) used to specify irregular forms, such as “corpus / corpora” or “take / took” and in inflectionally rich languages to enable the user to determine the correct paradigm of the word (such as “krava / -e” in Slovene).

Such inflected forms should be encoded in entry/form/@type=”inflected”, e.g.:

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>go</orth>  </form>  <form type="inflected">   <orth>went</orth>   <gramGrp>    <tns>past</tns>   </gramGrp>  </form> </entry>

...

4.6. Paradigms

When several inflected forms can be present next to the lemma, these can be embedded into the entry/form[@type=”paradigm”] element. The decision on whether to use this extra element depends on the particular dictionary and language.

The other use case for paradigms is when the full inflectional paradigm of the word is embedded in the entry, i.e. when the dictionary also includes all the word-forms of the words covered, which can be useful for e.g. machine processing.

An entry may contain several paradigms, e.g. a partial one for humans and a full one for machines, or one for each stem of a verb. Each paradigm type should be distinguished by the form/@subtype attribute.

<entry xml:id="perder" xml:lang="es">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>perder</orth>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">verb</gram>  </gramGrp>  <form type="paradigm" subtype="present">   <form type="inflected">    <orth>pierdo</orth>    <gramGrp>     <per>1</per>     <number>sg</number>     <mood>indic</mood>     <gram type="voice">active</gram>    </gramGrp>   </form> <!-- other inflected forms (of present indicative) here -->   <gramGrp>    <tns>present</tns>   </gramGrp>  </form>  <form type="paradigm" subtype="preteritum">   <form type="inflected">    <orth>perdí</orth>    <gramGrp>     <per>1</per>     <number>sg</number>     <mood>indic</mood>     <gram type="voice">active</gram>    </gramGrp>   </form>   <gramGrp>    <tns>preteritum</tns>   </gramGrp>  </form> ... </entry>

4.7. Representation of variants

The representation of variation within a form is highly dependant upon the specifics of the features of the variation and the way in which they vary. However, as a general principle, variation may be encoded as form[@type=”variant”] and embedded within the parent element for which a subordinate feature exhibits variation.

4.7.1. Orthographic variation

Several kinds of orthographic variation may be distinguished. Below, we present some of the options with the corresponding examples.

Spelling variation due to change in language’s orthography convention:

<entry xml:id="Flussschifffahrt"  xml:lang="de" type="compound">  <form type="lemma">   <orth type="segmeted">    <seg>Fluss</seg>    <seg>schifffahrt</seg>   </orth>   <form type="variant">    <orth>     <seg>Fluss</seg>     <pc>-</pc>     <seg>Schifffahrt</seg>    </orth>   </form>   <form type="variant">    <orth notAfter="1996">     <seg>Fluß</seg>     <seg>schifffahrt</seg>    </orth>    <usg type="time">Vor 1996 Rechtschreibung Reform</usg>   </form>   <gramGrp>    <gram type="pos">noun</gram>   </gramGrp>  </form> .... </entry>

The following example is from american English in which due to the lack of official conventions for transliteration of Arabic orthography to the English (Latin) script, the initial vowel in the surname ‘Osama Bin Laden’ varies between ‘O’ and ‘U’:

<form type="lemma">  <pron notation="ipa">   <seg xml:id="ousma" corresp="#usma #osma">ow."sa.ma</seg>   <seg>bɪn</seg>   <seg>ˈlaːdn̹</seg>  </pron>  <form type="variant">   <orth type="transliterated">    <seg xml:id="osma"     corresp="#usma #ousma">Osama</seg>    <seg>Bin</seg>    <seg>Laden</seg>   </orth>  </form>  <form type="variant">   <orth type="transliterated">    <seg xml:id="usma"     corresp="#osma #ousma">Usama</seg>    <seg>Bin</seg>    <seg>Laden</seg>   </orth>  </form> </form>

4.7.2. Phonetic Variation

In this example, the entry contains the single orthographic form as a direct child of the lemma and phonetic transcriptions of the two roughly equally used variant pronunciations of the word 'caramel' from American English.

<entry xml:id="caramel-en" xml:lang="en-US">

<form type="lemma">

<orth>caramel</orth>

<form type="variant">

<pron notation="ipa">'keɹə"mɛl</pronNote: Is <form type="lemma"> <orth>caramel</orth> <pron notation="ipa">'keɹə"mɛl</pron> <pron notation="ipa">'kaɹmɫ̩</pron> </form>also a valid option?Do we have general rules when to introduce new <form> subelements when some property is multivalued?What would, for instance, happen if we had a single entry for a noun/adjective? Or, maybe more mainstream, different genders? <form type="lemma"> <orth>caramel</orth> <form type="variant"> <pron notation="ipa">'keɹə"mɛl</pron> </form> <form type="variant"> <pron notation="ipa">'kaɹmɫ̩</pron> </form> </form> <gramGrp> <gen>m</gen> <pos>f</gen> </gramGrp>?For multivalued propertiesCf. also the lemon fragment at: https://www.w3.org/community/ontolex/wiki/Final_Model_Specification#Forms :lex_privacy a ontolex:LexicalEntry; ontolex:form :form_privacy.:form_privacy a ontolex:Form; ontolex:writtenRep "privacy"@en; ontolex:phoneticRep "ˈpɹɪv.ə.si"@en-US-fonipa; ontolex:phoneticRep "ˈpɹaɪ.və.si"@en-GB-fonipa.Note: It seems to me that Jesse's question about whether to use separate form/pron or whether to squeeze <pron>s into a single <form> points out a lack of taxonomical complement to our picture. We might want to say that the former is for two taxonomically separable variants, whereas the latter is for variants that we lump together (perhaps there is a taxonomy that describes them, but we don't care in the dictionary at hand).Note: As for the noun/adjective, noun/verb, gender or animacy, etc. differences, my assumption was that the form is the same, and we discriminate at the level of sense. That is: a single <form>, *no* <gramGrp> directly under <entry> (for the conversion cases, A/N, N/V), and separate senses, each with its <gramGrp>.An interesting question raised by this sketch is what happens if the form is identical orthographically but distinct phonetically (e.g. "separate", verb vs. adjective). In such cases, we would need a parallel split inside <form>, and inside <sense>, and ideally a mechanism to relate them.>

</form>

<form type="variant">

<pron notation="ipa">'kaɹmɫ̩</pron>

</form>

</form>

<gramGrp>

<gram type="pos">noun</gram>

</gramGrp>

...

</entry>

4.7.3. Regional or dialectal Variation

In the following example from Mixtepec-Mixtec, there is variation in the form of the word for the city of Oaxaca between speakers from the village of Yucanany and the rest of the speakers. Since the Yucanany variety makes up only a small portion of the speakers of the language, this case of variation is represented as an embedded form[@type=”variant”] within the lemma. Note the use of usg[@type=”geo”]/placeName to explicitly specify this feature in addition to the use of the private language subtag (xml:lang="mix-x-YCNY") as per BCP 47.

<entry xml:id="Oaxaca-MIX" xml:lang="mix"  type="compound">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>    <seg>Ñuu</seg>    <seg>Ntua</seg>   </orth>   <pron notation="ipa">    <seg>ɲùù</seg>    <seg>nd̪ùá</seg>   </pron>   <form type="variant"    xml:lang="mix-x-YCNY">    <orth>Ntua</orth>    <pron notation="ipa">nd̪ùá</pron>    <usg type="geo">     <placeName>Yucanany</placeName>    </usg>   </form>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">locationNoun</gram>  </gramGrp> ... </entry>

4.8. Extensions to the TEI Dictionary schemaNote: In a discussion with Toma, this was rejected from Lex0 proper, because Lex0 attempts not to provide encoding options, so we would end up recommending the use of <lemma> etc. throughout, and that would never get the proposal past the Council.

TEI already has in place the principle where specific elements can also be expressed as a general element refined by its @type, e.g. ab/@type=”p” ≡ p or seg/@type=”word” ≡ w. We propose to apply the same principle to form, as this would make the lexical entries more compact and readable for the lexicographers as well as enabling better validation.

In particular, the following new elements would be added, following the suggested values of form/@type with the some extensions:

  • lemma ≡ form/@type=”lemma”
  • inflected ≡ form/@type=”inflected”
  • phrase ≡ form/@type=”phrase”
  • compound
  • multi-word expression
  • paradigm ≡ form/@type=”paradigm”

N.B. the new elements need definitions (attributes, content models) which need to be defined. In general, they should be equivalents or refinements of form.

Other changes:

  • paradigm should be added to the list of suggested form/@type values
  • @subtype should be added to form and is equivalent to @type of the refined element e.g. form[@type=”paradigm”][@subtype=”full”]≡ paradigm[@type=”full”]

Comment: the same principle could be applied to sense, so that sense[@type=”terminology”] would be equivalent to terminology; at least in Slovene dictionaries, it is common to have first all the senses of the entry, and then a “phrasal nest” and then a “terminological nest”. These two need to be modelled in TEI as senses, and this would make the structure clearer.

4.9. Original notes

  • The overall grammatical properties of a dictionary entry are encoded in entry/gramGrp rather than inside the lemma form, i.e entry/form[@type=”lemma”]/gramGrp is not used to specify the part-of-speech etc. of the entry.
  • The complete grammatical information of a given form/orth (or pron) is obtained by its sibling gramGrp or by the children of its ancestors.
  • make @type (e.g. “lemma”; default BTW) mandatory on <form>
  • the inflectional information of the word is given in nested form(s) and we introduce a container element for paradigm (i.e. oblique forms) e.g. form/[@type=”paradigm”]/form[@type=”inflected”]
  • an entry can have several paradigms, where it would be useful to have @subtype on form (currently not allowed). Examples where this would be needed are e.g.:
    • if a verb inflects according to two different conjugation classes (two iTypes)
    • one “paradigm” giving just one or two forms for humans to know what the paradigm is, and one for machines, containing the complete inflectional paradigm
    • @resp should be somewhere there for stuff that we add to the dictionary that’s not in the source (e.g. full paradigm)
    • what do we use for referencing external paradigms? @ana seems a bit abusive(?)
    • hiding extra stuff with rendition mechanisms
  • potential Schematron restriction preventing form/@type=”lemma” at sense level

Further cases to be potentially considered:

  1. “run”, verbal form, in a dictionary that splits entries (a.o.) according to the orthography+pos:

entry:

form/@type=”lemma” | orth: run

gramGrp | pos: v

sense: …

2. “run”, in a dictionary that uses only the orthography as the discriminator:

entry:

form/@type=”lemma” | orth: run

sense:

sense/@n=1:

gramGrp | pos: n

….

sense/@n=2

gramGrp | pos: v

….

Comment 1: there is no gramGrp under <entry>, because the discrimination takes part within <sense>

Comment 2: I (Piotr) assumed that there is a single <sense>, recursive. I am not sure if this is a general assumption.

  • what do you do with paradigm information in the 2nd case? <form/@type=”paradigm”> within each sense

3. potential edge cases we might want to consider:

  • water - waters (specific sense with its own gramGrp),
  • staff - staffs vs. staves (new meaning for the historical but irregular plural form; possibly a separate entry with a cross-reference from “staff”), cf http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/staff
    • linkage as an additional mechanism apart from inheritance; in the prototypical case, the paradigm info down the tree is a restriction of the entry-level paradigm
  • ….

4. Further (non-edge) cases: orthographic variation, and the use of more than one orthographies within the same language. This should be treated the same as where a given form is being represented with more than one phonetic notation, e.g. as (i..n) orth or pron elements at the same level as direct children of form.

<entry xml:id="courage-heb" xml:lang="heb">

<form type="lemma">

<orth notation="menukad">אֹמֶץ</orth><!--'kitiv menukad': 'dotted'/'vowelized' spelling -->

<orth notation="male">אומץ</orth><!--'kitiv male':"full spelling" or "spelling lacking niqqud" -->

<pron notation="ipa">ˈomet͜s</pron>

</form>

<gramGrp>

<gram type="pos">noun</gram>

</gramGrp>

<sense>

....

</sense>

</entry>

5. simple and systematic (e.g. alternative pairs of forms, sg1-pl1, sg2-pl2)

Freedict swh-eng (pairs of forms):

<form xml:lang="sw" type="lemma">

<orth n="1">afisa</orth>

<orth type="variant" n="2">ofisa</orth>

<form type="inflected">

<orth corresp="#maafisa" n="1">maafisa</orth>

<orth type="variant" corresp="#maofisa" n="2">maofisa</orth>

<gramGrp>

<number>pl</number>

</gramGrp>

</form>

</form>

<gramGrp>

<gram type="pos">n</gram>

</gramGrp>

<sense>

<def>officer</def>

</sense>

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”>

<orth>run</orth>

</form>

<sense n=”1”>

<gramGrp><gram type="pos">verb</gram></gramGrp>

[information on the verbal senses]

</sense>

<sense n=”2”>

<gramGrp><gram type="pos">noun</gram></gramGrp>

[information on the nominal senses]

</sense>

</entry>

5. Structured lexical references (xr/ref)

Editors: Jesse, Katrien

Reviewer: Laurent

5.1. Motivation

The current TEI p5 guidelines provide several mechanisms by means of which one item of lexical information can refer to another, e.g.:

  • <gloss> for the provision of simple (non refined) translation equivalents of the head word
  • <usg type="synonym"> for synonym references
  • <citNote: This section draws the line between cit/quote used for examples and (here) xr/ref used for translation equivalents. With this extended treatment of translation equivalents not merely as forms that "appropriately contextualised, might ideally replace the source form in the translated text" but as actual references to a _potentially_and_in_most_cases_abstract_ dictionary "on the other side", I am wondering about what could be done with proverbs and idioms that are used to illustrate the usage of (forms of) headwords. Do we also encode them as xr/ref, because there is nothing wrong with postulating that they are references to an abstract dictionary of proverbs or idioms, or do we encode them as cit/quote, because they are examples?I am not trying to nitpick for the sake of nitpicking -- I am just trying to explore the boundaries of our potential recommendations.Note: I'm also still very uncomfortable with the idea of basing our translation equivalent mechanism on the notion of potential entries in potential dictionaries. I think we need to revisit this and see for isntance why this couldn't be covered by cit type translation and @corresp attribute or even <form>, something definitely to discuss in berlinNote: The same logic you oppose to, is applicable to the proposal of cit type=equivalent. Where are you quoting from? type="translation"><quote>...</quote></cit> for translation equivalents in bilingual or translation dictionaries
  • <oRef>, <pRef> for the resolution of “~" headword placeholders in quotations and other dictionary text0
  • <xr>, <ref> as a general cross-referencing mechanism
  • <ptr>, http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-ptr.html
  • <link>, http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ref-link.html
  • <mentioned> in the etymology section
  • <term> for mentions of technical terms

In keeping with the approach of the TEI-Lex0 initiative, and considering that links/relations between lexical data elements are increasingly part of the core lexical data model rather than mere convenience pointers for dictionary users, we need a more unified and more constrained mechanism for lexical references, whether they point to an existing lexical entity in some dictionary or lexicon, or in a more general way to lexical objects without a target reference.

The proposed mechanism has the following properties

  1. It applies only to references with a clear linguistic meaning.
  2. The number of arbitrary (or context-dependent) choices for the encoder is minimal; the semantics of the reference should not depend on context
  3. The relation between the encoding dictionary content and the underlying/implied lexical data model should be as transparent as possible
  4. No drastic changes to the TEI guidelines are needed, except for minor changes within the dictionary module

In the following we first present the recommended encoding, and then elicit how existing alternatives can be replaced accordingly.

5.2. Proposal: Using <ref> and <xr> to point to lexical entities

To unify lexical references, we propose to use <ref> as the general element for a lexical reference and to use <xr> as the enclosing element that groups information related to this reference. The reference may be internal to a dictionary or pointing to an external source, even when the actual target lexical object is not explicitly known. In the latter case, <ref> can be used without an explicit pointing attribute. Furthermore the actual intended target of the reference can be of various possible types, namely a full entry, but also a specific sense, form or morpheme within a given entry.

For all such usages, the following attributes may be used on <xr> and <ref>:

  • type is a mandatory attribute on <xr> for a lexical reference. Its default value is “lexical" and can be superseded (or complemented by means of @subtype). It should be an indication of the lexical relation between the headword of the entry and the object referred to (cf. next subsection)
  • ref/@type may be an indication of the target object category (entry, sense, ….)
  • xml:lang, which is recommended when <ref> actually contains an explicit lexical form
  • ref/@target: to point to the actual lexical object being pointed at when applicable
  • ref/@notation1: to indicate, like we currently do on <orth> or <phon>, the actual notation used for the explicit lexical form when provided

The most simple use of <xr> and <ref> according to the present guidelines would thus look like: <xr type="lexical"><ref xml:lang="he">pneuma</ref></xr> (in replacement to the existing example:<mentioned>pneuma</mentioned> in the TEI guidelines).

5.2.1. Typology for xr/@type values

Note: we should change cognate examples as <cit> as covered in the section about <etym> (to be included when Jack is finished with it.

We suggest an extensible list of values, including “cf" for general references which do not have clear semantics.

value of @typedescriptionexample
lexicaldefault (root of hierarchy)
cognatelink to cognate in other language
<entry>  <form type="lemma">voice</form>  <etym>   <xr type="cognate">    <ref xml:lang="sa">वाच्</ref>   </xr>  </etym> </entry>
etymonlink to (possibly reconstructed) root form
<entry>  <form type="lemma">voice</form>  <etym>   <xr type="etymon">    <ref target="http://indo-european.info/pokorny-etymological-dictionary/u%CC%AFek%CA%B7.htm"     xml:lang="PIE">u̯ekʷ-</ref>   </xr>  </etym> </entry>
synonym, hyponym, hyperonym, antonym , meronym (etc.) <entry>
<form type="lemma">
<orth>dog</orth>
</form>
<sense>
<xr type="hyperonym">
<ref xml:lang="en" type="entryNote: What does @type="entry" mean? A local reference? If yes, why not use @target="#e-2323" or similar?">mammal</ref>
</xr>
</sense>
</entry>
translationtranslation equivalent
<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>horrify</orth>  </form>  <sense>   <xr type="translationEquivalent">    <ref xml:lang="fr">horrifier</ref>   </xr>  </sense> </entry>
cfUntyped cross-reference<entry>
<form type="lemma">
<orth>borcht</orth>
</form>
<xr type="cf">
<lbl>Cf.</lbl>
<ref xml:lang="nl" target="#M012340">burcht</ref>
</xr>
</entry>

5.2.2. Suggested values of ref/@target

Cf: http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SAXP

  • # + id: reference to element by id inside current document
  • URI reference
  • xpath/xpointer expressions, using TEI xpointer schemes (http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SATS)
  • #null: there is no concrete reference

5.2.3. Replacement of current encoding

descriptioncurrent encodingproposed encoding

<quote>elle était horrifiée par la dépense.</quote>
</cit>

<orth>horrify</orth>
</form>

</xr>

<quote>she was horrified at the expense.</quote>

<quote>elle était horrifiée par la dépense.</quote>
</cit>
