<ref target="http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/191378?rskey=WgfOMW&amp;result=2&amp;isAdvanced=false#eid">stray</ref>
</xr>
</colloc>
</gramGrp>

5.2.4. Problems/open ends

  • If the reference is the encoding of a lexical/semantic relation between two linguistic units, it may be desirable to indicate the sourceNote: I am a bit lost here -- an example would be great to have. The null assumption for me would be that whatever the <xr> is contained in is the source of the reference, but maybe I am following the Editor's thinking here when I imagine that sometimes, the <xr> may need to be buried lower in the structure, but still the arc in the abstract reference graph would need to start somewhere higher up in the entry data structure?Note: The problem was purely hypothetical. We should maybe omit this of the reference more explicitly. Is it the current entry, the current sense, the current quotation?
  • Whether the <xr> pointing mechanism also applies to the <cit type="etymon"> from Jack/Laurent’s etymology paper, needs to be looked into.

5.3. <xr> and <ref>: further examples

5.3.1. Simple cross-reference to an entry

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>borcht</orth>  </form>  <xr type="crossReference">   <lbl>Cf.</lbl>   <ref target="#M012340">burcht</ref>  </xr> </entry>

5.3.2. Translation equivalent

1) There is a pointer, specified in the attribute “target", to some dictionary containing the word referred to

<entry>
<form type="lemma">
<orth>dog</orth>
</form>
<sense>
<xr type="translationEquivalentNote: I would suggest a simple "equivalent" here ==> cf. LMF Part 4 (TEI serialization)">
<ref xml:lang="fr" type="entry" target="http://www.cnrtl.fr/definition/chien">chien</ref>
</xr>
</sense>
</entry>

2) same, but there is no concrete reference (in this case target is omittedNote: just making a note with reference to my previous comments on null or absent `@targets`, so that this example is potentially easy to locate, once we reach some decision)

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<entry>
<form type="lemma">
<orth>dog</orth>
</form>
<sense>
<xr type="translationEquivalent">
<ref xml:lang="fr" type="entry">chien</ref>
</xr>
</sense>
</entry>

5.3.3. More complex example including quotations

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>dog</orth>  </form>  <sense>   <xr type="translationEquivalent">    <lbl>Male or unknown gender</lbl>    <ref xml:lang="fr" type="entry">chien</ref>    <cit>     <quote xml:lang="fr"> Le matin j'ouvre au <xr type="headwordAttestation">       <ref type="entry">chien</ref>      </xr> et je lui fais          manger sa soupe. Le soir je lui siffle de venir se          coucher</quote>     <bibl>RENARD, Poil de Carotte, 1894, p. 102.</bibl>     <cit type="translation"> <!-- included in the french cit, otherwise relation is lost -->      <quote xml:lang="en">In the morning, I open the door            for the dog, and i ...</quote>     </cit>     <bibl> <!-- If the translation is from a published source, there could be a bibl here as well -->     </bibl>    </cit>   </xr>   <xr type="translationEquivalent">    <lbl>Female</lbl>    <ref xml:lang="fr" type="entry">chienne</ref>    <cit xml:lang="fr">     <quote>6. Les fleuristes, murmura Lorilleux, toutes des          Marie-couche-toi-là. Eh bien! Et moi? reprit la          grande veuve, les lèvres pincées. Vous êtes galant.          Vous savez, je ne suis pas une <xr type="the_type_formerly_known_as_oref">       <ref type="entry">chienne</ref>      </xr> , je ne me          mets pas les pattes en l'air, quand on siffle! </quote>     <bibl>ZOLA, L'Assommoir, 1877, p. 681.</bibl> <!-- possible translation -->     <cit type="translation">…..</cit>    </cit>   </xr>  </sense> </entry>

5.3.4. Synonym, hyperonym, etc as (part of) a definition (“synonym definition", “genus proximum”)

<entry>  <form type="lemma">   <orth>dog</orth>  </form>  <sense>   <def> Four-footed barking over-enthusiastic <xr type="hyperonym">     <ref type="entry">animal</ref>    </xr> , best friend of      man; is a <xr type="hyperonym">     <ref type="entry">canine</ref>    </xr>   </def>  </sense> </entry>

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

5.4. Original text of this section:

5.5. (original bullets)

  • we’re looking for a mechanism to represent external references with some additional information
  • currently different patterns: xr+ref,xr+ptr; <xr type=”syn”></xr>
  • we could recommend using <lbl> inside <xr> so that we don’t leave text dangling
  • proposal: remove text node from the content model of xr, but add model.entryPart (in order to complement / put some additional context for xr)

5.6. General principles

There is a feeling that we need a more unified approach to lexical references, whether they point to a concrete dictionary entry/sense in some lexicon, or point in a more general way to lexical objects belonging to a category/namespace.

In the current guidelines, one can find, for instance

  • <usg type=”synonym”>W</usg> for synonyms
  • <cit type=”translation”><quote>W</quote></cit> for translation equivalents in bilingual or translation dictionaries
  • <oRef>, <pRef> for the resolution of “~” headword placeholders in quotations and other dictionary tekst
  • <xr>, <ref> as general crossreferencing mechanism,
  • <mentioned> in the etymology section,
  • <term> for mentions of technical terms

The proposal we seem to have reached a consensus on is:

  • Use <ref> as the general element for a lexical reference
  • Use <xr> as the enclosing element that groups information related to this reference
  • The attribute “type” on <ref> will be a indication of the target object category (entry, sense, … whatever
  • The attribute “type” on <xr> will be an indication of the lexical relation between the headword of the entry and the object referred to
  • We should work towards a rigid set of types of reference for lex0, but including “other” or “cf” for general references which do not have clear semantics
  • The content model of <xr> should be modified to include all of model.entryPart
  • The content model of <xr> should not allow text nodes

Current guideline definition is:

<xr> (cross-reference phrase) contains a phrase, sentence, or icon referring the reader to some other location in this or another text.

For lex0, this definition would have to be generalized to include “dangling” references to lexical objects without a target reference

5.6.1. Using <ref> to point to lexical entries

The present guidelines recommends to use <ref> as a single pointing mechanism to other lexical entries, in replacement to the following possible alternatives that in general make the current TEI guidelines fuzzy/equivocal as to how to implement such references, in particular <mentioned>, TBCompleted ... In the following we first present the recommended use of <ref> then elicit how existing alternatives can be replaced accordingly.

The usage of <ref> that is recommended here cover various types of cross-entry references, whether internal to a dictionary or pointing to an external sources, comprising the case when the actual target lexical object is not explicitly known. In the latter case, <ref> can be used without an explicit pointing attribute. Furthermore the actual intended target of the reference can be, within the lexical remit, of various possible types, namely a full entry, but also a specific sense of form within a given entry.

For all such usages, the following attributes may be used on <ref>:

  • @type is a mandatory attribute on <ref> for a lexical reference. Its default value is “lexical” and can be supersede (or complemented by means of @subtype)
  • @xml:lang, which is recommended when <ref> actually contain an explicit lexical form
  • @target: to point to the actual lexical object being pointed at when applicable
  • @notation5: to indicate, like we currently do on <orth> or <phon>, the actual notation used for the explicit lexical form when provided

The most simple use of <ref> according to the present guidelines would thus look like:

<ref type=”lexical” xml:lang=”he”>pneuma</ref> (in replacement to the existing example:<mentioned>pneuma</mentioned> in the TEI guidelines).

=> explanation concerning replaced elements

=> necessity to have a fine grained typology for @type

5.7. XR Examples

1: translation equivalent, there is a pointer, specified in the attribute “target”, to some dictionary containing the word referred to

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

….

<sense>

<xr type=”translation_equivalent”><ref xml:lang=”fr” type=”entry” target=” ….”>chien</ref></xr>

2: same, but there is no concrete reference (in this case target is omitted)

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

….

<sense>

<xr type=”translation_equivalent”><ref xml:lang=”fr” type=”entry”>chien</ref></xr>

3: more complex example including quotations

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

….

<sense>

<xr type=”translation_equivalent”><lbl>Male or unknown gender</lbl><ref xml:lang=”fr” type=”entry”>chien</ref>

<cit>

<quote xml:lang=”fr”>Le matin j'ouvre au <xr type=”the_type_formerly_known_as_oref”><ref type=”entry”>chien</ref></xr> et je lui fais manger sa soupe. Le soir je lui siffle de venir se coucher</quote>

<bibl>RENARD, Poil de Carotte, 1894, p. 102.</bibl>

<cit type=”translation”> <!-- included in the french cit, otherwise relation is lost -->

<quote xml:lang=”en”>In the morning, I open the door for my|the dog, and i ...</quote>

</cit>

<bibl> <!-- If the translation is from a published source, there could be a bibl here as well --> </bibl>

</cit>

</xr>

<xr type=”translation_equivalent”><lbl>Female</lbl><ref xml:lang=”fr” type=”entry”>chienne</ref>

<cit xml:lang=”fr”>

<quote>

6. Les fleuristes, murmura Lorilleux, toutes des Marie-couche-toi-là. Eh bien! Et moi? reprit la grande veuve, les lèvres pincées. Vous êtes galant. Vous savez, je ne suis pas une <xr type=”the_type_formerly_known_as_oref”><ref type=”entry”>chienne</ref></xr>, je ne me mets pas les pattes en l'air, quand on siffle!

</quote>

<bibl>

ZOLA, L'Assommoir, 1877, p. 681.

</bibl>

<!-- possible translation -->

<cit type=”translation”> ….. <cit>

</cit>

</xr>

</sense>

4: synonym, antonym, holonym, meronym, hyponym, hyperonym and other lexical relations

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

<xr type=”hyperonym”><ref type=”entry”>mammal</ref></xr>

5: synonym, hyperonym, etc as (part of) a definition (“synonym definition”)

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

<def>Four-footed barking over-enthusiastic <xr type=”hyperonym”><ref type=”entry”>animal</ref></xr>, best friend of man; is a <xr type=”hyperonym”><ref type=”entry”>canine</ref></xr>

6: We keep <colloc> for collocations, but the referencing mechanism could be used inside <colloc> to point to the relevant entry/sense

<entry>

<form type=”lemma”><orth>dog</orth></form>

….

<colloc>

<xr type=”colloc”><ref type=”sense” target=”some_id”>stray</ref></xr>

</colloc>

7: Whether the <xr> pointing mechanism also applies to the <cit type=”etymon”> from Jack/Laurent’s etymology paper, needs to be looked into

6. Usage information

In the current TEI guidelines, <usg> is defined as an element which marks up “usage information in a dictionary entry”. Prototypically, usage information is a label which can be attached at various points in the entry hierarchy in order to signal e. g. restrictions in terms of geographic regions, domains of specialized language or stylistic properties for the particular lexical item that it is attached to.

6.1. Label-like vs. narrative usage descriptions

Usage information ca be provided in dictionaries both in the form of label-like descriptors (often abbreviated) and as fuller narrative expressions.

Consider, for instance, the following senses taken from a German entry for Pflaume “plum” where usage information is provided by labels taken from fixed sets of values for stylistic and diatopic properties:

<sense n="1">  <def xml:lang="de">Frucht des Pflaumenbaums</def>  <def xml:lang="en">fruit of the plum tree</def> </sense> <sense n="2">  <usg type="register" norm="colloquial">ugs.</usg>  <def xml:lang="de">Pflaumenbaum</def>  <def xml:lang="en">plum tree</def> </sense> <sense n="3">  <usg type="style" norm="casual">salopp</usg>  <usg type="style" norm="expletive">Schimpfwort</usg>  <def xml:lang="de">ungeschickter, untauglicher Mensch</def>  <def xml:lang="en">awkward, ineligible person</def> </sense> <sense n="4">  <usg type="geo" norm="regional">landsch.</usg>  <usg type="style" norm="casual">salopp</usg>  <def xml:lang="de">anzügliche, leicht boshafte Bemerkung</def>  <def xml:lang="en">offensive, slightly mischievous remark</def> </sense>

In contrast to the example above, the following sample features an occurrence of a more verbose usage description that does not rely on a fixed vocabulary. The sample is taken from a Serbian dialect dictionary. The quote in the dialect is further qualified by a usage hint: “(said by a peasant woman in the field in hot weather)” which provides a particular context in which the quote was recorded.

<cit type="example">

<quote>„Ду́ни, ве́тре, се́јче леб да пе́че”</quote>

<usg type="hint">(рекла сељанка на њиви за време врућине)</usg>

<bibl>(<placeName>Дубница</placeName>).</bibl>

</cit>

6.2. Types of usage informationNote: frequency information in a dictionary: usage? (corpus based dictionary with frequency information)oldest attestation: date + location of oldest attestation of an entry in a corpus based dictionary: usage?

USAGE FURTHER INVESTIGATED: https://docs.google.com/document/d/10xxYwTSrAk1otrkOCZCIwE79VhTjObqmTRhpKosipyU/edit#heading=h.selhcccybq1y

<usg> is a typed element. The type of a <usg> element can be conceived as a conceptual axis (independent from other types) along which the given value of the element is located. The TEI guidelines offer a range of sample values for types to illustrate potential uses of <usg>:

usg@typeSvensen 2009 expandedconceptual axisexample value
geoplacegeographicgeographic area
timetime–temporal, historical eraarchaic, old
dom xtechnicalitydomaindomain or subject matterscientific, literary
reg

social cultural; formality;

attitude?

registerregister
style???–stylefigurative, literal
plevfrequency?preference levelpreference levelchiefly, usually
langOUTlanguagename of a language mentioned in etymological or other linguistic discussion;
gramOUTgrammaticalgrammatical usage
synOUTsynonymsynonym given to show use
hyperOUThypernymhypernym given to show usage
collocOUTcollocationtypical collocate of the headword
compOUTcomplementtypical complement
objOUTobjecttypical object
subjOUTsubjecttypical subject
verbOUT–typical verb
hintOUT–unclassifiable piece of information to guide sense choice
?text typepoet., lit.
normativitynon-standard
mediumcolloq., spoken ...
nationality?? what is the difference with diatopic?Lat., Fr.,

It is recommended that for TEI-Lex-0:

  1. The @type attribute is made mandatory.
  2. The element <usg> should be used in a narrower sense than is currently the case.
  3. The @norm attribute should be encouraged.

Justification:

  1. Without type attribute, <usg> would be an underspecified element. Usage labels describe a wide range of linguistic phenomena. Classifying them should be considered a good practice.Note: Datawork, challenging!
  2. Currently, the TEI guidelines contain an overuse of <usg> for describing phenomena that could be covered by alternative, more narrowly defined TEI elements. It should be considered a good practice to use the most specific TEI element available. See next section Restricting the scope of <usg>.
  3. It is good practice to normalize the values of the <usg> elements because dictionaries are not always consistent in the way they use their usage labels. For instance, we could have abbreviated and unabbreviated labels in the same dictionary. TOMA TODO: add examples from Vuk. Normalization should be only restricted to a single dictionary, not a global normalization effort.

6.3. Restricting the scope of <usg>

  1. Do not use <usg type=”lang”> to mark up the name of a language in an etymological or other discussion. The recommended way to encode this information is using <lang> element within <etym>.
  1. INCORRECT
<entryFree xml:id="MZ.RGJS.сајдисльк">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>сајдисль́к</orth>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">м</gram>  </gramGrp>  <usg type="lang">тур.</usg>  <sense>   <def>уважавање.</def> … </sense> </entryFree>
  1. CORRECTNote: adapt to recent decisions
<entry xml:id="MZ.RGJS.сајдисльк">  <form type="lemma">   <orth>сајдисль́к</orth>  </form>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="pos">м</gram>  </gramGrp>  <etym>   <lang value="tr">тур.</lang>  </etym>  <sense>   <def>уважавање.</def> … </sense> </entry>
  1. Do not use <usg type=”hyper”> or <usg type=”syn”> to mark lexical relations such as hyperonymy or synonymy. The recommended way to encode lexical relations is using the reference mechanism provided by <xr type=’syn’>. TOMA TODO: add examples
  2. [collocNote: I am now looking at some data from Milena Hebal-Jezierska (will ask her to contribute the examples), and she rather ingeniously uses [cit/quote type="collocation"], essentially assimilating examples with collocates to general examples (with a different @type, and some extras, like <oRef>). This way, we can use full grammatical description inside the collocate <cit>, so there's no need to squeeze stuff into @type. @type="preposition" is totally horrible..., comp, obj, subj, verb]: WE STILL NEED TO WORK ON THIS, they overlap. Our current thinking is: do not use <usg type=”colloc”/> or any of these, but rather <colloc type=”object”/> or <colloc type=”preposition”>.

In the following example from a Serbian-German-Latin dictionary, the sense of the adjective дангубан (futile, wasteful) is labeled with a collocate: н. п. посао (e.g. job).

  1. INCORRECT

<entryFree xml:id="VSK.SR.дангубан" sortKey="дангубан">

<form type="lemma"><orth>да̀нгубан</orth></form>

<!-- etc.-->

<gramGrp source="#digitalEd"><gram type="pos">adj.</gram></gramGrp>

<sense xml:id="d1e162786">

<usg type="colloc">н. п. посао</usg>

<cit type="translation">

<quote xml:lang="de">was viel Zeit verlieren macht</quote>

</cit>

<!-- etc.-->

</entryFree>

  1. CORRECT

<entryFree xml:id="VSK.SR.дангубан" sortKey="дангубан">

<form type="lemma"><orth>да̀нгубан</orth></form>

<!-- etc.-->

<gramGrp source="#digitalEd"><gram type="pos">adj.</gram></gramGrp>

<sense xml:id="d1e162786">

<colloc type=”noun”><lbl>н. п.</lbl> посао</colloc>

<cit type="translation">

<quote xml:lang="de">was viel Zeit verlieren macht</quote>

</cit>

<!-- etc.-->

</entryFree>

  1. <usg type=”hint”> should be used as fallback for cases where the usage information do not fall into one of the recognized cases discussed above.
  2. <usg type=”dom”> (domain) is used to specify the (e.g. scientific, professional etc.) domain in which the annotated lexical information (e.g. a sense, a cit etc.) is used.
  3. register
  4. style
  5. <usg type=”plev”> Frequency information information on lexicographic entities may differ from other types of usage information in that it often cannot be interpreted without further context. In phrases such as “mostly biology” or “rarely used in American English” it serves the purpose of a modifier (quantifier) to another usage information (or other lexical information). Such use calls for modeling the frequency information as an attribute to the usg element modified. For frequency information provided explicitly (e.g. corpus frequencies), a separate element should be introduced.

This is a bad idea:

<usg type="plev">chiefly</usg> <usg type="domain">biology</usg>

because there the plev doesn’t actually qualify the domain usg.

Are we then proposing something like <usg type=”domain” freq=”high” norm=”biology”>chiefly biology</usg>

potential issues:

  • is freq=”high” equal to “chiefly”, “mostly”, “often”
  • is freq= “low” the same as “rarely, seldom”
  • is freq the right name? or scope?
  • how likely is this to be adopted by the Council? I don’t think we have a frequency attribute, do we?

Theoretically, one could do something along the lines of:

<lbl>chiefly</lbl> <usg type="domain" norm="biology"><certainty locus="value" cert="high"/>biology</usg>

I think this is a stretch, because this is really not about certainty but frequency.

ticket to nest <usg>?

making usg recursive is difficult

this is a very specific case, might be taking things too far for TEI-Lex

sync attribute in the first usg?

<usg type="plev" synch=”#usg1.1”>chiefly</usg> <usg xml:id=”usg1.1” type="domain">biology</usg>

more stuff to think about:

  • Frequency and source corpus? ie. source attribute <usg type=”frequency” unit=???? source= “this_and_that_corpus”>12</usg>
  • gram? keep it? → future work; check with TEI community ACTION POINT. “gram” is used for things we wouldn’t keep in //gramGrp; it rather specifies a (typical?) grammatical context (CHECK with real world applications)
  • comp should go, is really colloc? → again look for examples obj, subj, verb: again.
  • Compare set of types with Toma’s table (TODO)

Samples

https://github.com/LingSIG/Dictionaries

N.B.: copyleft status of eZISS?

Sample from Althochdeutsches Wörterbuch, feel free to annotate:

Text:

aba-nemanto adv.; vgl. mhd. abenemende part.-adj.

(vgl. Findebuch S. 2). - Graff 11,1063 s. v. abaneman.

aba-nemend-: -o Np 45,10 (Ausg. K.-T getrennt

geschr.); -a Npw 9 (getrennt geschr.).

etw. beendend, mit abstr. Akk.: uuieo tuot er diu?

abanemendo dia uuiga . unz ze ende dero erdo aufe-

rens bella usque adfines terrae NpNpw 45,10 (= Npw 9).

Here is a typical WNT dictScrap (“kopje”) (http://gtb.inl.nl/iWDB/search?actie=article&wdb=WNT&id=M073402)

— VERKEN —, znw. onz., mv. -s. Oorspr. is verken de alg. vorm in de mnl. schrijftaal, doch deze wordt naderhand, vooral in de 17de e., door holl. varken verdrongen. Verken, dat buiten Holland de gewone vorm in de dial. is, komt nog bij zndl. schrijvers voor. De uit het mnl. bekende meervoudsvorm varken, verken vindt men nog in de 16de en 17de e. (O. Rechtsbr. v. Steenb. 81 [1504]; Gem. Duytsche Spreckw. H 5 r° [1550]; gruterus 2, 129 [1611]; zie nog cats 2, 320 b [1656], echter in het rijm); de eveneens mnl. formatie varkene(n), verkene(n) komt nog tot in de 17de e. voor (v. dillen, Bedrijfslev. Amst. 1, 199 [1550]; Utr. Placaatb. 3, 674 a [1617]). De thans eenig gebruikelijke meervoudsvorm op -s is pas in de 15de e. voor het eerst aangetroffen (posthumus, Leidsche Textielnijverh. 1, 157 [1436], R. v. Zieriks. 281 [1485].) Het verkl. verksken (zie Teuthon. [1477]; junius, Nomencl. 57 a [1567]; kil. [1574]; heerman, Annot. 207 a [1642]) is in Z.-Nederl. de gewone vorm (j. joos, Schetsen en Schertsen 124 [1906]); varkske(n) (timmermans, Anna-Marie 47 [1921]) sluit aan bij een gedepalataliseerd brab. varken. Thans in de cultuurtaal alleen varkentje.

Mnl. verken, varken naast ouder verkin (reeds 1208 als bijnaam, zie H. Top. Dial. 20, 54), varkin; mnd. verken, varken, nnd. ferken, farken, varken; nhd. ferken (< nd.). Verken is de uit germ. *farχîna- ontstane umlautsvorm (zie v. wijk [1912]) met depalatalisatie tot varken en overgang χ > k in de inlaut (verg. hd. ferkel < ohd.farhilî(n)). Eig., evenals veulen en kuiken, het ter aanduiding van het jonge dier gebruikte gesubstantiveerde neutrum van een met -în-suffix gevormd bnw. (verg. lat.taurînus, suînus) — met een diminutieve bet., die in het mnl. soms nog merkbaar is — bij germ. *farχaz: oeng. fearh, neng. (veroud.) farrow (verg. to farrow); ohd. farh, farah, mhd. varch, nhd. (dial.) farch, fark ”big, varken”; verg. zwe. fargalt ”ever”; buiten het germ. lat. porcus; iersch orc (< *pork); lit. pa᪇szas ”gecastreerd varken”; ksl. prasę ”big”. Zie verder Ts. 67, Afl. 2.

7. References

  • Parthenos WP4 standards library at GitHub: https://github.com/ParthenosWP4/standardsLibrary with a collection of dictionary samples (many in TEI formats) under Lexicography/ENeL-WG2/Dictionary Samples/
  • V. papers on “logical structure” of MRD/LDBs:
    • Ide, N., Kilgarriff, A., Romary, L. (2000). A Formal Model of Dictionary Structure and Content. Proceedings of Euralex 2000, Stuttgart, 113-126.
    • Erjavec, T., Evans, R., Ide, N., Kilgarriff, A. (2000). The CONCEDE Model for Lexical Databases.. Proceedings of the Second Language Resources and Evaluation Conference (LREC), Athens, Greece, 355-62.

Example discussed at ENel WG2 Budapest

  • Example from A DICTIONARY OF MANGAREVA (OR GAMBIER ISLANDS)

The original text:

AGAI ( àgài), adopted or adoptive. Ex. Motua agai, an adoptive

father, a foster­father. To nurse; to nurture. To give food to. 2.

To manure the ground. 3. To impregnate female flowers with

those of the male.

Aka­agai, to nourish; to feed. Plural akaagaigai.

The TEI-Lex0 encoding:

<entry>

<form type="lemma">

<orth>AGAI</orth>

<pc>(</pc> <pron>àgài</pron><pc>)</pc> <!-- dictscrap vs pc -->

</form>

<sense n="1">

<sense>

<def>adopted or adoptive.</def> <!-- should/could translation equivalent rather than <def> -->

<cit type="example">

<lbl>Ex.</lbl>

<quote> Motua agai,</quote>

<cit type="translation">

<quote>an adoptive father, a foster­father.</quote>

</cit>

</cit>

</sense>

<sense>

<def>To nurse; to nurture. To give food to.</def>

</sense>

</sense>

<sense n="2"> 2.

<def>To manure the ground.</def>

</sense>

<sense n="3">3.

<def>To impregnate female flowers with

those of the male.</def>

</sense>

<entry>

<form type="compound">

<orth>Aka­agai,</orth>

</form>

<sense> to nourish; to feed.</sense>

<form type="inflected">

<gramGrp>Plural akaagaigai.</gramGrp>

</form>

</entry>

</entry>

8. X. Misc. examples

8.1. X.2.

from Milena Hebal-Jezierska’s Czech-Polish dictionary (discussed after the meeting in Budapest).

Piotr’s suggestion follows (and it’s meant as food for thought / basis for discussion):

Please note: (1) I am not taking a stance on how to encode equivalents. I simply used what I felt relatively comfortable with. (2) I had nothing to say about <usg> -- I copied Milena’s suggestion.

I see several issues that are particularly worth discussion here:

  1. <colloc> However we decide to encode it, let us use a solution that offers structural space for grammatical (and other) description of the collocate
  2. note the highlighted @resp at the level of <cit>. This is Milena’s “intrusion” into the scanned data. She is responsible for the <cit>, so it should be “@resp-able”. Probably nearly every element inside the entry should. OR: we (ab)use @decls mechanism for descriptions of such changes. OR (best?) we create a @tlex:change attribute that references a single <change> in the <revisionDesc>.
  3. I used <oRef> on purpose here, because I got startled when I saw the <xr> alternative. I am not saying it’s wrong, but I think we also need a shorthand expression (I will add some prose on that)
  4. “kuty na cztery nogi” is an idiomatic expression headed by the passive adjectival participle kuty. It would be lemmatized under kuć , probably as a <re> (or an equivalent). I mention this to make sure that, if we end up using <xr> for encoding translation equivalents, we also find a way to handle such cases.

8.2. X.3.

From Joanna Bilińska’s Budapest presentation

Entry that we’ve arrived at in Budapest:

<entry>

<form type="lemma">

<orth>BODŁO</orth>

<pc>,</pc> <!--we don't like this, need better solution for commas-->

</form>

<form type="ending"><orth>a</orth>

<pc>,</pc>

</form>

<gramGrp>

<gen value="neutrum">n.</gen>

</gramGrp>

<sense>

<def>bobo, straszydło, potwora, dziwotwor, </defNote: these are translation equivalents>

<cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">einNote: And this "ein" is weird. It goes for all these three (masculine) nouns, and it actually signals "masculine or neuter" (unless the dictionary uses something extra to mark German neuters)Note: You could assume ellipsis here and the other two two equivalents would actually be "ein Popanz", "ein Unhold" – unfortunately we do not have @expand at hand … Schreckbild</quote></cit>

<cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">Popanz</quote></cit>

<cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">Unhold</quote></cit>

<cit type="example">

<quote>Trudno dać wiarę, by to przecie bodło Podnieść cały wóz jedną ręką

mogło.</quoteNote: and this quote here consists of two verses. This is signalled by the rhyming "bodło"-"mogło" and by the capitalization of the "Podnieść". I wonder if we can encode this information (it may of course remain implicit).Note: quote/l or even quote/lg/l><bibl>

<author>Opal.</author> <title>poet.</title> <biblScope>8.</biblScope></bibl></cit>

<cit type="example">

<quote>Okrutnym przerażona bodłem. </quote><bibl><author>Pot.Note: "Pot." and "Stryjk." are actually abbreviated author names, so we should probably reference the authors listed in the header. Same goes for the titles.</author> <title>Arg.</title> <biblScope>324.</biblScope>

<author>Stryjk.</author> <title>Gon. U.</title> <biblScope>3.</biblScope></bibl></cit>

</sense>

</entry>

[Page]

Decisions 2 May

Some general points:

to do: pruning the possible contents of elements we use in TEI lex0; eg. entry

Discussion on entry:

In TEI lex0

  • entry recursive
  • No superentry and related entryNote: We should take into consideration cases where <re> figures within sense, which means we need to open a ticket to make that possible (Not sure if this would be wlecome by the TEI guys). See Arabic examples and English example below
  • typing entries: to be discussed - check literature (Axel); mandatory?? (keep in mind dictionaries of proverbs; collocation dictionaries; dictionaries of idioms)

Ticket:

  • recursive entry because of superentry (too limited)
  • send examples (Arabic -Mohammed ; hause (Axel); Buddhist dictionary (Laurent); Chinese (Jesse)

Discussion on etymology / xr / bilingual dictionaries

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F57EB_zSMPAtDTuAaWC_iRxNQoy4QbjR63t0oWRe4sI/edit?usp=sharing

  • everywhere where there is a form: use “form”
  • cit type=cognate/etymon/descendent for etymology and within: form and @corresp when you want to link to somewhere else
  • cit type = equivalent for bilingual dictionaries and within: form and @corresp when you want to link to somewhere else
  • unresolved: “a certain plant” in cit type=equivalent
  • classical references, eg. see also 1.1, use <xr><ref>
  • ref is allowed inside of def; examples???
  • references in etymology that are a bibl refering to extended description: bibl with @corresp when wanting to link to external source list
  • def and gloss: to do: look at examples, from both etymological dictionaries and dictionaries with an etymological section (everyone look for examples)

Usage

  • lexical relations: xr typed (hyperonym, hyponym, synonym, meronym…)
  • ticket: clean up usg in tei guidelines, get rid of obj, subj etc… use colloc instead…
  • adopt table of Svensen in tei lex0 and provide a kind of mapping with the labels used before,
    <usg type=time datcat=”diachronic”> declaration on dariah github; it needs further clarification (good examples). Toma resends the article and will also look into Hausmann [Toma + Katrien] - frequency info {check paper Laurent, not happy with the implementation - but happy with conceptual description}

XML-ID

  • PID (handle) for the resource / CLARIN
  • mandatory XML-id per entry (means also related entry)
  • recommendation to have id’s for elements you think it is important to be able to reference to (eg. in Elexis: sense id’s necessary)

Recommendations on how to do encode idioms, collocates, proverbs etc. (Katrien, Toma)

PLANNING FOR LJUBLIANA

  • Make a new version TEI-Lex0.current + put link of the new version in the legacy version
  • Add a section examples to each subject
  • Add real life examples (everbody)
  • Usage: Toma + Katrien (Mohammed ~ put online)
  • Ref: Jesse + Katrien
  • Form: Pjotr
  • Etymology, add a new section: Jack
  • Entry: Laurent, Axel
  • Introduction:
